pros: Flexible, and interactive, and I was able to vastly expand my skill set.

pros: Despite wrongfully being targeted during the school's crackdown and stricture of campus Greek life, the music and visual arts house ("The Mill") persevered (bear in mind, we are not a Greek-affiliated organization, although we aim to be a place of expression and inspiration for any student). Due to the crackdown, we operated on a reduced budget and experienced tighter restrictions, however, through collective ingenuity and determination, our student team provided the community with dozens of art performances and showcase galleries featuring students' and outside artists' work. We look forward to continuing working with the school to improve this experience.
cons: It was difficult to work with the school to have performances. Due to their lack of communication and intent to restrict our operations, we almost were not able to have any performances or art shows whatsoever. The school's Student Involvement, Activities, and Leadership (SAIL) department needs attention. As students, we are happy to help partner with the school in restructuring SAIL's operations.

review_title: Great work culture, and great people
pros: I've been working at Trinity College for nine years now.  Like any job, it's got its highs and lows, but every day I drive to work I feel excited and challenged.  The best part about Trinity (even above the great benefits) is the people.  Almost all of the people that work here care about what they do, carry themselves professionally, and are always looking to make those around them better too.  It's a diverse, talented, and caring staff, and that makes for a work environment that is tough to replace, which sometimes people don't always remember.  There is also a new President at Trinity - a very warm person, but also someone that keeps expectations high, which is important at any top tier college.
cons: Some would argue that the location is a con.  I would argue the opposite.  Trinity is located in Hartford, Conn., a small city that has made great strides in recent years and is about five years away from being a city that people will want to live in, rather than have to.  For many, that change has already happened, mostly due to the thriving restaurant scene and noteworthy arts and cultural offerings of the city.  Hartford is basically a baby Brooklyn, but with better access to open fields, hiking trails, etc.  It's also an easy drive to both Boston and New York.

review_title: Great School if you find the right people

cons: If you don't find the right crowd of people, your experience may not be amazing.

review_title: Great college with standard small-school issues

cons: Significant town/gown problems with a high-end private college in the poorest section of Hartford. The lack of diversity only furthers that problem. The faculty is particularly dominant in campus affairs, more so than at other colleges.
